item.name: 7 Wonders
item.comment: This is where card-drafting and civilization games should learn from. Full stop. Expansions Leaders, Wonder Pack and especially Cities give it a nice extra combinations for thought and variability. (Don't bother with Babel.)

item.name: 7 Wonders: Cities
item.comment: Not such a big gameplay change as Leaders, but a nice addition, adding little bit of randomness (and thus deepening replayability). Also, increasing player interaction to more than just two neighbors. I would recommend.

item.name: 7 Wonders: Duel
item.comment:
7W2 has it all. A new drafting mechanics, that makes sense in two players (unlike exchanging of hidden hands), streamlined mechanics of army and science (both allowing sudden victory DURING the game, so another thing to watch out for), perfectly short and fast-paced length, a little bit of randomness in setup to keep it replayable... and even a little bit better looks than its namesake ancestor.
Any fans of 7 Wonders who get to play in two players (like with spouses, for example), this is a must-buy. Any other people, at least think about it and go check out some videos. This may well be the best competitive game purely for two that I played.

item.name: 7 Wonders: Duel â€“ The Messe Essen
item.comment: Unlike some other promos which have next to none game impact or are just fancy graphics... this one is actually a userful Wonder.

item.name: 7 Wonders: Leaders
item.comment: NOW this is getting strategic!

item.name: 7 Wonders: Wonder Pack
item.comment: Okay expansion for a great game. Does what it sets out to do. Buy it if you want more variability in your 7 Wonders games.

item.name: Abalone
item.comment: A good two-player filler. Look for alternative rules (wikipedia etc.) to make it more variable.

item.name: Ad Astra
item.comment: An interesting twist on the Settlers mechanic. Everything is really about timing your choices and guessing what other players did. Plus points for a sci-fi theme, seems rather rare.

item.name: Adios Amigos
item.comment: Quick and somewhat entertaining math-based speed-game. The theme and tokens adds nicely, even though it's pasted on.

item.name: Agricola
item.comment: A modern classic. Some people dislike the theme, but for me it still works better than cold war or nearly any warfare game.

item.name: Agricola CZ-Deck
item.comment: Nice for Czech background culture (wink wink), but unneccessary gamewise.

item.name: Akrotiri
item.comment:
A solid two player abstract. For us at the beginning it was kinda hard to see the patterns and it takes quite a lot of tablespace for a two-player game, but it's very well thought and innovative. The execution is very well done, nice illustration and sturdy components, especially the cute ship that can actually take up to 3 cubes (so a rule easily remembered).
Some goal cards might need recalibration, but that is easily done by a CD-marker (and you might arrive to a complete other conclusion, when it comes to goal difficulties) but the sheer amount of brain burning is admirable for such a simple and short game.

item.name: Alhambra
item.comment:
Solid gateway game, okay even for occasional play for seasoned gamers.
The expansion 2 (City Gates) makes it flourish the most, in my opinion.

item.name: Alhambra: The City Gates
item.comment: Very nice expansion, adds some mechanisms that were largely missing.

item.name: Among the Stars
item.comment:
Very very very good game. Some randomness to keep it replayable, some strategy to keep it enjoyable. Too bad there's so much text, so my non-English-speaking friends can't enjoy it with me. And the sci-fi theme just clicks for me. The rules for two players are somewhat messy, but the game flows very nicely in three. It can take up fourth player easily, fifth is somewhat difficult and the sixth makes it overlong, the game really shines in 3-4.
Ambassadors checked out. Neat. They add some player decisions, especially when it's good to invite them. AND you get to build the ambassador's bureau, so inviting him is not a lost turn.
This is easily one of the top5 in my 150+ games collection. The only downside is very much tablespace and the scoring between each turn considerably slows it down, but I guess there's no way to avoid that. :(

item.name: Among the Stars: The Ambassadors
item.comment: The Ambassadors add what this game needed: A bit of complexity and a bit of decision freedom. The best part of inviting ambassador is not the inviting itself (they can bring some neat bonuses, but only very few are worth of the lost turn), but you get to build his/her bureau. You get bureaus in all five types, so you get to build a green building (in case you need one) even though your hand lacks green. AND it's cheaper than most buildings AND you get some bonus in the Ambassador's ability. Timing is everything here.

item.name: Amyitis
item.comment: A solid euro. The theme feels more pasted-on than your usual eurogame (like this literally has NOTHING to do with planting a garden) and it wouldn't hurt Ystari to throw in a camel miniature rather than camel token, when it's supposed to move so often... but the core mechanics have some interesting thoughts.

item.name: Arkadia
item.comment: I was surprised how good this was. A lot of decisions, everyone affecting everyone, I especially like the changing values of seal tokens.

item.name: Atlantis Rising
item.comment: Luckfest. Nice looking one, but still luckfest.

item.name: Attika
item.comment: Nice... if rather unpredictable... mechanics. On the other hand, I wouldn't call it random - you really do have some say what's going to happen. The art is poor, though. Requires some thinking, not very heavy.

item.name: BANG!
item.comment: Ugh. Like a beer fun, maybe. But the game is heavily imbalanced, very much luck-dependent and a game that throws someone out 10 minutes in play and then drags for another hour... no.

item.name: Bohnanza
item.comment: Some fun, largely about negotiating. Take it or leave it. Not my cup of tea, but not terrible, either.

item.name: Cacao
item.comment: Nice little tile-laying with a neat theme, that doesn't go too deep, but also doesn't drag too long for how simple it is.

item.name: Camel Up
item.comment: Well done filler. Heavily luck dependent, but some fun and a little cutthroat with pretty components and very cleverly made dice-pyramid.

item.name: Castellion
item.comment: It might be my love to tilelaying, but this is very worthy addition to the Oniverse. I like it probably more than Sylvion. No hand to manage and immediate risk-weighing makes this something new to play. Like it quite a lot. :)

item.name: Castles of Mad King Ludwig
item.comment:
First and foremost, not a bad game. I'll gladly play it again. Sadly for Mad King, there's one game out recently, which does nearly the same thing better.
So why do I think Isle Of Skye is superior to Mad King Ludwig? 1) The graphics of game components. Sorry. 2) The theme. I understand this is just my personal preference (my wife and I visited British isles just this autumn, while the castles just remind me of our dreadful high school history teacher :-/ ), but then again, this is my personal game evaluation. 3) IoS can take 5 players. 4) The Mad King tiles don't follow some trivial square grid to be seen. I get it, that's thematic for mad castles, but changing the tile angle or position by less than a millimetre will suddenly make some doors not fit, even though they're supposed to be fitting. That won't happen to you in Skye, with a plain Carcassone-like square network. 5) The four random shared goals are scored just once in Mad King, at the end. For as little as 2 points, this feels kinda anti-climactic. 6) Being a master builder is a HUGE advantage. A *huge* one. That's a normal thing in games, 1st player is somehow better or worse each round than all other players - but if that's the case THIS much, there should be a mechanism making sure that all players have been first the same number of times.
And to be fair, why is Mad King better than Isle of Skye? 1) It has a prettier box. That's where the "prettier" stops. 2) The different little effects triggered when closing a room are one extra nice thing to think about. Sadly they are scarcely a game-changer. But sometimes even little differences matter! :) 3) Examining the function of your built castle might bring some funny talks - "So, to bring the food from kitchen to dining room, the cooks have to go thru catacombs and meditation room. Great..."
TL,DR: Not a bad game. But unless you're a big middle-ages architecture fan, rather go check out Isle of Skye.

item.name: Caverna: The Cave Farmers
item.comment: When compared to Agricola, this game is definitely more forgiving. You still struggle with time to perform everything you wanted, but you are not completely screwed if someone else took the action you wanted. The absence of ability cards is somewhat a minus for me (I prefer "play with what you've been given" and Variable Player Powers, rather than everything is fair to everyone), but there are still plenty of paths to victory given by the various rooms. Will yet have to try this with more than 2 people. Definitely a plus to be support 7 players, although the table would have to be enormous and the players would run from here to there.

item.name: Caylus
item.comment: The whole thing works. It just feels very dry and non-thematic. I guess even board games could age.

item.name: Chicken Cha Cha Cha
item.comment: Pexeso++. Good for kids and that's it.

item.name: Citadels
item.comment: Meh. Heavily random. Some bluffing, in the end it's all about second guessing. Not my cup of tea.

item.name: Cleopatra and the Society of Architects
item.comment: I guess it relies quite a lot on the appeal of 3D palace rather than the very gameplay. Still, the idea of "be corrupt indeed, but not the MOST corrupt" does have some appeal. Cute children's game.

item.name: Codenames
item.comment: Outstanding party word-game. However I disliked Vlaada in the past, here I bow down. Extra plus points for a purely-cooperative variant.

item.name: Crows
item.comment: More or less good game lifted by greatly chosen theme. Though the graphics could have been better, it somewhat fits. Very nice components, good game, okay graphics, terrible box. Depending on your group, you can have some terrible downtime.

item.name: Cyclades
item.comment:
It looks amazing and colorful, I'll give them that. However, with only two Gods allowing some movement on the board, you get to spend most of the game sitting and regretting you weren't the one player who gets to move this turn. I definitely don't recommend 3-player game.
EDIT: The expansions help this game to bloom quite a bit.

item.name: Day & Night
item.comment: A solid game with good looks and some appeal due to asymmetricity. The outlook is heavily dependent on card draws and too bad the player pieces are tokens, not miniatures... but overall, a keeper.

item.name: Diavolo
item.comment: The best dexterity game out there for us math-geeks. Too bad there's so little amount of us. :)

item.name: Discworld: Ankh-Morpork
item.comment:
It stroke me quite as a surprise, that a game created in spirit of an exisiting fictional world - is actually good even game-wise. This is a fun game that spot on finds the balance between decisions (to keep it interesting) and randomness (to keep it replayable). While it might be interesting even for non-fans of the books, it's a must for any gamer+Pratchett fan, such as myself.
EDIT: After few plays, struck down to 6.5 . I thought we just can't play it properly, but it proves very much luck-driven.

item.name: Dojo
item.comment: Wonderful little and quick filler :) The theme has little in common with the gameplay, but what it sets out to do, it does really well. Some nasty backbitting, some luck pushing, all a 15 minutes fun.

item.name: Drako
item.comment: Kudos to Adam Kaluza for being able to create a game so heavily asymmetric, yet truly balanced. Great fun and challenging hand management, while also watching the board positions. Some extra plus points for the graphics and theme, the pictures are one of the best I've seen in board games and the miniatures crave coloring.

item.name: Dungeon Petz
item.comment: I tried this as a promise to myself I will try a third Vlaada (after being disappointed by Galaxy Trucker and repulsed by Prophecy) to find out what the world sees in his games. I still don't know. Then again, I'm probably biased by now. This is an average worker placement euro. If you get over the wannabe funny and longish manual, there is some meat in the game (figuratively AND literally!) and the theme is more interlocked with the mechanisms than it usually is in euros. Plus, growing your boardgame tamagotchi pet is neat. Having said that, there are too much mechanisms and some of them rather unfair, the scoring is difficult to make sense of... and the artwork is trying too hard to be cute. For half of the total playing time, the players are solving separate puzzles (of assigning needy-cards to their pets, so all the needs can be covered), which feels very solitaire. If you like Vlaada or need your euro in Czech, well go for this (but you've been warned), otherwise check out the Ystari menu.

item.name: Dungeon Twister 2: Prison
item.comment: Not bad a two-player game. Maybe too many fiddling factors for any real strategy - and maybe just not entirely my cup of tea.

item.name: DVONN
item.comment: One of the best two player abstracts. Requires chess clock to prevent AP.

item.name: The Dwarf King
item.comment: The card suits have illogical colors (Green Dwarves, Red Goblins? WTF?) Other than that, beautifully illustrated funny little game. Heavily luck-dependent, but it does offer some strategy, it's kinda funny and quickly over. Great for beer with friends in a pub, when you don't have that much place on the table to play something complex.

item.name: Elysium
item.comment:
This is what a modern board game should be. Relatively short playing time, tough decisions on simple rules, considerable replayabilitity due to mixing the cards the way you have mood for, lovely theme and each of the 8 god families illustrated by a different person. And nice insert, that's not a standard in this type of games. (Greetings Seasons, another great exception to crappy inserts.)
The only downside is the schematic graphics is sometimes too schematic and the two halves that compose the player board don't fit exactly graphically. Also, preparation and teardown could be a chore, but it's hard to find a nice rich game without such chore.

item.name: Empires of the Void
item.comment:
Not bad. Nice graphics, the battle outcomes are somewhat random, the diplomacy growth and strategy options somewhat limited to make players focused on fighting, which might be preferable for some players, but not for me.
Also, ship miniatures would be largely preferable to the tokens. But probably very expensive.
I would play this again, but I don't feel the need to own this.

item.name: Favor of the Pharaoh
item.comment: Not bad for what it is. Yathzee-style dice, trying to roll better, while increasing your chances to mitigate the result. Egyptian theme is welcome, but really pasted on. With the lightness of the game overall and quite a lot of luck, I'm surprised it deserves this big and fancy box. I guess that's the American game design. Still a keeper, my wife loves dice.

item.name: Fearsome Floors
item.comment: Party fun and cute theme, but heavily random.

item.name: Felix: The Cat in the Sack
item.comment: Cute kittens and a nice little bluffing game, quick to learn, quick to teach. Bought for my cat-loving girlfriend and not regretting.

item.name: Five Tribes
item.comment: Neat game all in all. Quite AP-prone, though, and lots of fiddly rules to remember for this length of gameplay. I wouldn't mind playing it from time to time, but my gaming group has too many AP-prone members to be worthy of owning it.

item.name: Flash Point: Fire Rescue
item.comment:
Interesting at first sight, gets samey and boring after like four plays. Maybe this theme just doesn't cut it for me, but for me, Ghost Stories is the cooperative games' holy grail.
EDIT: Traded away.

item.name: Fluxx
item.comment: Keeping up with the ever-changing rules is a slight fun, but overall very much luckfest. No control about who wins whatsoever - which is a normal thing for Looney Labs.

item.name: Forbidden Desert
item.comment: A cute family coop game. The difficulty feels somewhat random and artificial, but then again, a sand hurricane also appears random. It's engaging and fun to react to whatever just randomly happened. Definitely recommend this over Pandemic (as they see it's a re-re-implementation), because of the modularity of the board.

item.name: Fresh Fish
item.comment: For something so simplistic, surprisingly fun, especially the backbitting in the closing part of the game. Definitely better in more people.

item.name: Friday
item.comment: Very nice single player game, the principle just works. And that's coming from someone who doesn't like deck building.

item.name: Friday the 13th
item.comment: Funny almost-party game that differs very much in different player counts. But the main mechanism is not "push my luck", but really "screw you". All in good taste, though. The "Friday 13th" fresh retheme has a very cute illustrations, albeit the square cards are peculiar to hold.

item.name: Frutti di Mare
item.comment: Definitely not deep and somewhat random, but a good profit-based filler with a cute theme.

item.name: Galaxy Trucker
item.comment: The real-time and tactial building of a ship don't mix together very well. For the second "half" of each round, you just sit around and watch your ship fall apart. That's not a game, that's a TV show.

item.name: A Game of Thrones: The Board Game (Second Edition)
item.comment:
One of my greatest boardgame disappointments. A game where the very mechanics allow players to fight together against the winner, who got ahead by his strategy on his own, seems a lot unfair - and that's far from the only unfair mechanics. For example, in the supplies, it doesn't really matter AT ALL how much supplies you hold in the long term, or how much you gained or lost - it only matters in the extremely rare and totally unpredictable moments, when the supplies are calculated and updated. Plus, later turns rather drag on, with all the units that need their orders. The opening setup is heavily unbalanced, maybe in lieu of the story, but since I am a fan of board games and not of the GoT series, my total opinion is "no, thanks".
Plus, the only board game that GUARANTEES some heavy and evil quarrels among the players.

item.name: Ghost Stories
item.comment:
Hands down the best coop game there is. Decision tree large enough for one player not to dominate the whole game and beautifully crafted graphics fitting the theme really well.
I heartily recommend both official expansions, even though preferably not played at once.

item.name: Ghost Stories: Black Secret
item.comment:
Interesting twist on the game mechanic, transforming the game from all-vs-game to one-vs-many. The Evil doesn't have it very easy though, which is interesting, considering even random Evil is pretty hard to beat in the base all-vs-game setup.
I love how Mr. Bauza creates the game easy to see, so you don't have to remember stuff, you see everything. There's even a token of the currently active player. And yes, it seemed needed. :)

item.name: Ghost Stories: White Moon
item.comment: Good twist on a great game. More decisions, less dificulty to win.

item.name: Hanabi
item.comment: Requires a few plays to see the depth. After that, you can't get enough.

item.name: Haru Ichiban
item.comment: Cute two-player filler with some difficult grasp on the overall strategy... not hard to understand the rules, but quite hard to play. The illustrations are very nice, almost dreamy.

item.name: Hive
item.comment: When it comes to hex-based duel games, I'd always prefer GIPF-series over this. But this is also an elegant game which is far easier to travel with than GIPF. So we play this on our vacations.

item.name: Hold Your Breath!
item.comment: Plain stupid. A lot of confusing and unexplained rules, too random even for a child game, nicely painted but weird game-wise.

item.name: Hooop!
item.comment:
Good family game with decent variability without being too dificult to explain to non-gamers. Kingmaking is bit of a concern here.
On a cuteness-meter (where 0 is Terra Mystica and 10 is Takenoko), this is a solid 9.

item.name: Ice Flow
item.comment: Not bad. Pinging polar bears to ruin someone's turn is fun. The game is a little broken, but that can be fixed with a simple rule "adding a new ice is only allowed AFTER the meeple's walk".

item.name: Imperial Settlers
item.comment: Relatively lightweight civilization builder with great PC-game-inspired artwork and theme. Gameplay is all about card combos and deciding what to do with what did you randomly drawn - which means some players can get really screwed by chance, however most cards have several ways to play them, so there's always room for decisions. The game is heavily asymmetric, which increases replayability, and supports even a special ruleset for single player mode. All in all, I'm not surprised it was so much of a hit of 2014! :)

item.name: In the Year of the Dragon
item.comment: Evil and short. Thats how I like my euros.

item.name: Infarkt
item.comment:
This is NOT a party game. This is a worker-placement hand management thing, too slow and dull for a party (or party-mooded non-gamers), too shallow for worker placement gamers. And laughing about death by cancer or depression is not only stupid, it's just plain horrible.
I played 200+ different table top games in recent couple of years. This and Munchkin are the worst ones I tried so far.

item.name: Ingenious
item.comment: The original name of the game is "simply genial" and it fits. This is game scraped to minimalism and that's why it's so good, perhaps.

item.name: Innovation
item.comment:
A few neat ideas, especially the resource management with unfolding your card piles. Illustrations are also not bad. Other than that, nice meaty game ruined by the fact that some of the cards are awfully strong and you see your civilization, built piece by piece in the last 20 minutes, to turn into dust in a mere turn. I guess this simulates the real civilizations, too... but as an euro player it's not something I want to see in my games. :)
I would prefer to play it house-ruled (eg. forbidding to activate the same card twice in one turn, because some cards are really mean) and I'll probably play again, but not rushing.

item.name: Isla Dorada
item.comment: The pictures are gorgeous, but there's no other illustration level to expect from Naiade. That guy is a genius. Also, nice gaming pieces. The game... more like meh. HEAVILY random for how long it takes. The auctions are just too little deciding agony, because you might even return to the auctioning AFTER you passed. If someone could take the same principle, but squeeze it under 30 minutes, this would make for a great game.

item.name: Isle of Skye: From Chieftain to King
item.comment:
This is what Carcassonne should have been (then again, Carcassonne was released a lot of years earlier). Also, this makes me wish the rating could go higher... I'm not going to reclick everything else a few degrees lower, but boy, Skye is a gem deserving an 11 at least. Why? First of all, having to connect paths in Carcassonne buggered me immensely (it's not an area of one color, merely a line) and this game neatly combines a little bit of set collection into the mix, while mitigating luck of the tile draw, because the players can purchase tiles from one another. Might be even a tad short for 2 players, but boy the decisions are agonizing on such simple rules!!! Also, only using 4 scoring tiles of 16 possible (where the order also matters) makes sure the game is going to be replayable a ton. I had to try several games just to see HOW MUCH is the gameplay and decisions different just because different things are scored this time around. Great job in game design!
A little bit AP-prone game, but as usual, that mainly depends on the gaming group. Killer of: Carcassonne, Mad King Ludwig.
Recommended: in 2 or 3 players each round draw one "dummy player tile", only one, to be purchasable from the bank for [round number] + 1 coins. Do not redraw it within one round (only one such tile per round, 6 per game), always redraw between rounds (even when not bought).

item.name: Istanbul
item.comment:
Rudiger Dorn is back! :) This is a very original and interesting twist on worker placement, fast paced and smart game. The principle of moving around your assistants and having to optimize your paths is very original, but still, the very actions offered on the "board" are also kinda different from a typical worker-placement fair. A lot of player interaction for an almost-euro (indirect interaction, but you still screw them by using some action before them, so it makes the action more expensive for them... and they need to pay you, if they meet you on the same card), lot of replayability thanks to modular board. Thumbs up and fingers crossed for Spiel des Jahres.
UPDATE: And yes, it won! Kennerspiel des 2014.

item.name: Jackal & High
item.comment:
Frankly this game got into my wishlist just be seeing the box's artwork, without knowing much about it. And surprisingly enough, it became one of my most replayed games. Fast filler with easy rules, yet interesting even for gamers due to high fun factor. Illustrations suit the gameplay really well (especially back of the cards displaying back of the jackals and hyenas, who "rip" the card through with their heads), most games are under in 10 minutes and - once more - really entertaining. I'd recommend this game to basically anyone. Go for it!
In the end, I wanted to say something I dislike about the game, but there really isn't much. The box, while small, could have been smaller considering the contents, but that's really just nitpicking.

item.name: JÃ¤ger und Sammler
item.comment:
This is what Hey that's my fish! should have been.
It's not a game I love mostly from the heart, but I give it such high rating because: - in its category, light family game, it does exactly what it sets out to do - it allows some clever thinking and even backbiting on rarely simple rules - the theme is nicely illustrated and doesn't feel unconnected - some people here, teh "true gamers", apparently tend to downrate a game just because it isn't complex enough... and I want to counter-balance them.
Not sure about the worldwide position of this game, but here in mid-Europe it's much more under the radar than it deserves.

item.name: K2
item.comment: Very decent game, in which the mechanisms do work quite well. You need to consider the balance between risk and reward, because climbing too high to risky peak may bring you no reward at all. Due to the theme not attractive for me, I don't feel very tempted to have it hit the table often, but definitely a keeper in my collection.

item.name: Karnivore Koala
item.comment: Cute idea for a game, but in the end quite random... the gameplay boils down to whoever randomly draws the needed card first. Great illustrations and puns on cards, but the gameplay just doesn't hold up. Still better than King of Tokyo, though... and miles better than another famous "game" where the gameplay can't match the card humour (The Munchkin of course).

item.name: Kemet
item.comment: If you're into army-based conquer-them-all games (which frankly I'm not), this might be one of the best choices out there. I love Egyptian/fantasy theme, the components are gorgeous and while this game is often compared to Cyclades due to similar looks, this thing kicks Cyclades's ass game-wise. Here you get to do things every turn - not just wait until you are able to pay for a god that you wanted. Plus, I don't think this game would bring quarrels between players, as Cyclades sometime do and Game of Thrones always does.

item.name: King of the Elves
item.comment: Not bad. Nice mechanisms that will make you really heavily decide (at least occasionally) on simple rules. The neat idea of paying by your victory points. My only complaint that bonus +10 points for visiting all cards on the table seems a tad too high. I'd recommend bonus of 2 times number of players.

item.name: King of Tokyo
item.comment: Push-your-luck, but funny and with a nice theme. Will just have to see what variable player powers the expansion brings.

item.name: Labyrinth
item.comment: Of course, with the simplicity it might get boring... but a great gateway game with simple rules, that really fulfills what it set out to do. Too bad the later spin-offs are such low-par.

item.name: Lanterns: The Harvest Festival
item.comment: Nice little abstract game for families. Not many rules so everyone can understand it quickly... and beautiful components. The rules on gaining tokens are little bit tricky, but overall a keeper. Light and cute thing to end the gaming evening with. :)

item.name: Last Will
item.comment: While I admit the game description "be the first to spend all your money" sounds awesome and original, this particular execution of the idea soon gets into luck-driven tedium. The choice of actions is too limited, player interaction close to zero, your combos heavily dependent on lucky draws and the graphics is clunky and, to say the truth, pretty ugly. If you want a good variable worker-placement euro with small interaction, but big effectiveness-competition, get Agricola.

item.name: Lewis & Clark
item.comment:
PROS: - components, neat meeples
- the card illustrations
- a few neat mechanisms (eg. all workers are neutral, count well how much do you need) and interesting ideas in the card deck
- The game really punishes you for counting things wrong, you lose the position on the "victory river" for anything surplus you had in the moment of recycling your deck. This is what I consider a good thing, euros in general should reward optimization and good thinking.
CONS: - The overall theme doesn't sell it for me. Some might like the game precisely for the theme, though.
- The among-player interaction (traditionally lower in euros) is not high here, too. I wouldn't mind that... but generally the player interaction feels very random. I seriously doubt with all my hand management I have to do anyway, I would still have some brain capacity to watch which neighbors-affecting symbols to use and which ones to avoid... One card just has too many various effects.
- Every action you plan, every movement on the "victory point river" takes SEVERAL TURRRRNS to launch. Everything here feels slow, especially the deck building.
The last two "cons" might gradually disappear with more plays, but at the moment I'm not rushing into that... :(

item.name: The Little Prince: Make Me a Planet
item.comment:
A good and light filler, that can be played meanly if desired. However, when it comes to light set-collecting fillers from Antoine Bauza, I'd always choose Dojo over this. Plus one point if you especially like the book.
EDIT: Neat bluffing variant for two players. +1 for that.

item.name: Lord of the Rings
item.comment: Nice game, maybe a little too simple in rules, but very heavy to balance what you need and what you may sacrifice.

item.name: The Lord of the Rings Labyrinth
item.comment:
From the game point of view, a decent reimplementation of the Master Labyrinth with a little deeper strategy - completely ruined by the corridor graphics. Even in normal daylight, it's kind of hard to make out what's a wall and what's a passage.
If you want some game from the Labyrinth family (which is a nice game understandable for children, yet giving some nice brain twisters to keep adults interested), go get the very first original.

item.name: Lords of Xidit
item.comment: Delightfully tight and with easy option to piss off friends... but not in an evil way. Plus, the illustrations are naÃ¯ade. I mean, gorgeous.

item.name: Love Letter
item.comment:
Okay family game, which is fun in the right group but should be playable in more people to truly shine.
Sadly, Love Letter gave birth to the game format called "micro game" and most of them are crap with too little decision trees. This one is fine, though, as micro games go.

item.name: The Magic Labyrinth
item.comment: Very nice children game. Get the expansion for greater adult-appeal. :)

item.name: Mamma Mia! Plus
item.comment: Good twist on card-based memory games - for once, you don't have to remember position, but NUMBER of the cards. Well-chosen theme for the mechanism, doesn't feel pasted on.

item.name: Mangrovia
item.comment: Cute little family game. Works really well in various player counts thanks to carefully balanced dummy huts. Nice theme and illustrations.

item.name: Manno Monster
item.comment: Boy it's funny! The graphics seems odd at times, but it serves its purpose... it's not that hard to remember six different monster drawings. The rest is pure logic-powered fun.

item.name: Marrakech
item.comment: No real appeal for core gamers, but very nice filler to explain to non-gamers and GOD it's cute, the actual minicarpets!

item.name: Marrying Mr. Darcy
item.comment: This was clearly made by a lover of the novel, but definitely not a game designer. You build up for nearly half an hour to have everything ruined by a single bad die throw. The mechanisms are too random to apply any tactics, let alone strategy. Nice, but not great illustrations, a terrible game. Good only for occasional laughs (with the zombie module) and for lovers of the novel.

item.name: Mascarade
item.comment: Tested once. It's supposed to be fun, but it felt just like a random bunch of events. Before you have the chance to catch up what's going on, the round is over.

item.name: Master Labyrinth
item.comment: A bad spin-off of the okay original game. Labyrinth makes much more sense with players concealing - and not sharing - their goals.

item.name: Metropolys
item.comment: Very clever game! Not frequently does a game bring so much thinking on so little rules! Thumbs up. However, the board does look too clunky.

item.name: Meuterer
item.comment: Pretty complex for a game with just a deck of cards. That's not necessarily a bad thing. Clever scoring system requires a lot of tactical thinking and pushing your luck. Heavily recommended, if you can get your hands onto a copy in a comprehensible language. ;)

item.name: Mexica
item.comment: The rules just plain don't make sense.

item.name: The Mole in the Hole
item.comment: As a children's game... why not.

item.name: Monstermania
item.comment: Good filler for kids. Not much to find underneath and you need really a good lit table to tell green from yellow.

item.name: Morels
item.comment: The game rules are almost cruel. Some challenge, some luck and it's really difficult to get what you want when the card-deck-decay is so fast. Nicely chosen theme, even though finding cider and pans in the forest doesn't make much sense. :)

item.name: Mr. Jack Pocket
item.comment: Good asymmetric bluffing-deduction game with a reasonably small box.

item.name: Munchkin
item.comment:
No game stating "all rule disputes should be solved by loud arguments among players, with the game owner having the last word" in its RULEBOOK can be good. This is pure mess, leaving so many subtle dependent rules on the players that I wonder why they bothered to have a rules manual in the first place. That's not what game design should look like.
Other than that, loooong and boring random bunch of events with runaway scoring and bash-the-leader, where the only fun is from reading cards. Do yourself a favor, don't ever buy this, go to a teahouse, lend Munchkin, spend a few minutes reading the cards having laughs and then go play an actual GAME.
EDIT: Yesterday I watched it played again. Isn't that just annoying how players can decide to screw your cards and combos in YOUR turn, in the time when the control should be yours? I just wish the BGG evaluation could go below 0, to express what an abomination this is.

item.name: Myrmes
item.comment:
Very nice and well-balanced euro with gorgeous plastic ants. However, the manual is far from clear and well-written. A few things aren't explained at all and the rest is noted in a confusing order. However the designer was very open to my questions.
EDIT: Raised to 10, due to replayability-appeal.

item.name: New Dawn
item.comment: First play in 2. The engine building does have a nice feel, but the options what to do with the resources are quite limited. Time will tell how best to combine it, or whether it's heavily draw-dependent, I'd definitely raise the hand limit from four to five (it's the same number as the player's technology limit or bases-of-one-type anyway). The game makes it pretty hard for a player who fell behind to raise from the bottom. Definitely prefer AtS over this, but I don't regret the purchase and we shall see how will it turn out after a few plays.

item.name: Niagara
item.comment: I don't really understand the awards and high rating. The game has undeniably outstanding looks, but mechanics-wise feels there's little space to maneuver player decisions. And I don't think that's a purpose. :)

item.name: Ninja Camp
item.comment: Does what already has been done better in Jager und Sammler, but this one is more gamer's game with more decisions... AND more portable. It definitely deserves a place in your collection, if you tend to try interesting beer & pretzel games. Cute illustrations, nice theme.

item.name: Noah
item.comment: A cute and easy filler. Too bad the Noe is a token, not a miniature. Very luck driven, but it's short, so you odon't feel bad for losing once or twice. Other than that, nothing to say against it.

item.name: Nox
item.comment: A nice game for trolling opponents and being mean, but the abrupt ending of a round really feels there's not much control on the outcome.

item.name: Ochs & Esel
item.comment:
Great party game.
Bumping this one to 10. It's so scarce to meet a game supporting 8+ players with so little downtime per player.

item.name: Odin's Ravens
item.comment: A perfect choice for all the evil mean-heads out there. :)

item.name: Olympos
item.comment: I guess there might be a good game underneath all the layers of confusing rules... but I haven't dug that deep yet. EDIT: My second playing sparked my interest again. MANY things to choose from, prone to AP. But overall an interesting game.

item.name: Onirim
item.comment: People say the pictures in this game are ugly. I like them very much. They somewhat fit the dreamy theme. So far the only single-player game I've seen that actually has the appeal to play it in single-player, again and again. I also like the idea of three optional expansion modules directly in the box.

item.name: Onirim (second edition)
item.comment: Granted, there's a lot of solo games I haven't tried. I am yet to try any solo LCG... but still, I have played a lot of games and this one is the most replayable solo game ever. This experience will be hard to beat. I also like the graphics, strange and out of this world, fits the theme perfectly.

item.name: Origin
item.comment:
Nice components to look at (even though the pawns could be better integrated into player discs), neat illustrations, an okay game with a little bit of challenge, little bit of randomness and VERY little player interaction. It really comes down to how lucky you are during drawing objectives, but for such a short game, randomness is not a problem. Seek this if you want an area control more family-friendly than Small World or Metropolys.
6/10: I won't seek it or own it, but I wouldn't decline an occasional play.

item.name: Panic Lab
item.comment: Not a bad game... but definitely not for everyone. You de facto run a simulation of canalcrawling-mutating algorithm in your head - and try to be the fastest to evaluate it correctly. People of some professions have an obvious advantage here.

item.name: Patchwork
item.comment: Very nice filler for two with super-simple rules and yet tricky enough. The game feels it's cut very short by the time track, but that's probably by design, to make the scoring tight. Nice theme that is not represented in board games very much and doesn't even feel too much pasted on. The compononets could have been real buttons and a spool instead of general wooden figure, but that's something a local purchase in dressmaker-shop can fix. :)

item.name: Pocket Rockets
item.comment: Okay game with a very little replay-desire... I guess even a great designer had to start somewhere. At least the box is small and sturdy.

item.name: Potato Man
item.comment: Nice and surprising take on trick-taking games, especially the surprising evaluation of tricks. Almost push-your-luck, because due to forced NON following of the suit, you never know when will the round end and you'd have to discard the strong cards you saved.

item.name: Pyramid
item.comment: Great bluffing game, pure funsies on simple rules understandable by kids. Kudos to M-A. C. Merkle for the idea of a great bluffing-memory-deducing game played on a vertical board.

item.name: Quarriors!
item.comment: Deck/pool building is not my cup of tea... you buy a solid card/die or two and then spend the rest of the game waiting for them to come again. Having said that, this one is a good pool building.

item.name: Quarto!
item.comment: The game is great. Just too quickly over.

item.name: Ra
item.comment:
This might just be the best - and definitely most accessible - auction game there is. The theme is pasted-on, but why not Egypt... and the rules are VERY well-balanced. The idea of "sun paid by me becomes a property of the player who wins auction after mine" is especially clever, creating another strategic thing to watch out for.
In short, rarely there is a game providing so much space for decisions on so little rules. Some say Knizia's masterpiece is Ingenious, Euphrat and Tigris etc. For me, while those are a rock-solid games, this is really the peak of his work. AND unlike Euphrat, this withstands the test of time.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy
item.comment: An over-combined mess.

item.name: Raj
item.comment:
(Vulture-and-mice themed edition, "Sup aby to vzal" in Czech, the box looks the same as "Hol's der Geier".)
This is really a game stripped to very basic fundamentals. And yeah, funny bluffing.

item.name: Rat Hot
item.comment: Cute, fast and good spatial tactics for two.

item.name: Rat-a-Tat Cat
item.comment: Too much luck-based, for my taste.

item.name: RattleSnake
item.comment: Hah hah hah. My gf loves magnets.

item.name: Rattus
item.comment: Surprisingly entertaining plague-spreading game with a lot of "eat it!" factor. And not much else. The character cards are kinda oversized, but the whole thing can still fit on an average table, so no problem in the end.

item.name: Red7
item.comment: Very nice. This little abstract card game is what Fluxx desperately tries to be: Fun, fast-paced, cleverly designed, thinky and yet gives the players a decent amount of control over the ever-changing rules. The only sad thing is that it can be played in a maximum of four players; but mechanics-wise, that's understandable.

item.name: Relic Runners
item.comment:
A solid family game with very cute looks, DoW overdone themselves. A nice variability to victory. Isla Dorada killer.
After playing this and Elysium, Mathew Dunstan is definitely a man to keep an eye on.

item.name: River Dragons
item.comment:
Cute looking, some mutual blocking and bluffing fun with the Dragons card, some rules are pretty mean, but that's fine for a quick game.
You have to be very careful though, the planks tend to easily fall apart (physically).

item.name: Saboteur
item.comment: I don't know. The main thought seems to have some appeal, but it's nigh impossible to play with the saboteur identity hidden enough and yet win.

item.name: Samurai Spirit
item.comment:
Toinito did it again! Granted, the decisions are so subtle that they may seem simplistic, but that is how to make the game fast enough, so it doesn't drag waiting for your turn even in 7 people. I'd like to know, if the people who said "the decision were really random and obvious", in the reviews here, actually WON. It's not easy.
It really does matter when to support, which raiders to defend (instead of confront), even when to pass and drop out, to recognize you're more of a harm to the team now. Apart from that, pretty action-packed illustrations, nice samurai meeples and the small size of the box was a pleasant surprise.

item.name: Scoville
item.comment: Lovely theme and mechanics. Dont be fooled by the childish graphics though, the game can be pretty punishing and unforgiving... choosing the right position in the round is both crucial and tough. Cute peppers, but in not-perfect light recognizing the colors might be troublesome. The player meeples are too tall and clunk the view. Still, check this if you like euros with cute theme. :)

item.name: Seasons
item.comment:
From my collection of 100+ games, this is my favoritte. The combinations are nigh endless and it's always a nice brain-teaser with an incredibly great look.
Kudos to the insert designers, this box goes against the unwritten rule "the more complex and interesting is the game, the duller and shoddy the box".

item.name: Sewer Pirats
item.comment: Nice set-collecting fun with some backbiting and gorgeous miniatures.

item.name: Shadow Hunters
item.comment: I guess kill-each-other card games just are not my cup of tea. Still, a better party game of this style than Bang! and probably even better than King of Tokyo, even though that's hard to compare.

item.name: Shadows over Camelot
item.comment: THIS is the most famous coop? Really? Not bad, but far from epic-greatness of Ghost Stories, elegant simplicity of Hanabi, unpredictability of Pandemic or lovely theme of Yggdrasil.

item.name: Shear Panic
item.comment: Cute sheep. The game feels somewhat unbalanced, but it does provide some brain twists.

item.name: Sitting Ducks Gallery
item.comment: Only as a fun in a drunk company of good friends, that won't mind shooting each other's ducks away. But indeed, in this occasion it IS funny.

item.name: Small World
item.comment: Some pure territory control fun. Simple yet great. I don't get it, I hate amerigames, am a strong pro-euro player, but for some reason I loathed a typical euro Carcassone and love this, which they say is American. Don't think so, but still... :)

item.name: Small World: Tales and Legends
item.comment: A good twist. "High Noon" for Small World.

item.name: Solo
item.comment: No need to buy a special deck for these game mechanics.

item.name: Space Walk
item.comment: This game will somehow remain as a special place in my heart - I made a Windows version of it, with graphics and artificial opponent, as my bachelor thesis. So yeah. :)

item.name: Spot it!
item.comment: Quick to explain, quick and fun to play, easy to travel. Good choice if you want to own just ONE eye-speed game - mainly because it contains five different playing principles.

item.name: Spyfall
item.comment: Fun for like 5 gaming sessions. I suppose it must get old pretty quick, due to the limited amount of predefined locations. However, I'm the first to admit storytelling games aren't my cuppa in the first place.

item.name: Sushi Go!
item.comment: Cute art. That's it. No meaningful decisions, no knowledge of deck balance (you know what's in the total deck, but not what it's there this round), just choosing something and hoping for the best. You could easily throw a die instead, to simulate the level of control you have.

item.name: Sylvion
item.comment: Onirim is still my favorite Oniverse game. Having said that, I definitely don't regret having this in my collection. The game perhaps isn't as deep as Onirim with 7 optional expansions, but the deceptive depth lies on a different place. And boy, it is a lot meaner! 8-)

item.name: Ta YÃ¼
item.comment: There's really nothing bad to say about it. It's not a deep strategy, but does very well what it sets out to do. My edition is made completely from plastic, which thanks to pieces and board engraving makes it easy for the pieces to stay put (unlike Ingenious) and it's even possible to play in a whirlpool (tested). There's not many boardgames that could survive that unharmed. :)

item.name: Taj Mahal
item.comment:
Yet another elegant auction game from their master, Reiner Knizia, in his golder years. Many paths to victory, some inpredictability, some strategy. Will never turn down a game of this.
The artwork will not take your breath away, but not repulse you, either.

item.name: Takenoko
item.comment:
This game - and this game alone - made me return to boardgaming hobby after cca. 10 years and raise my collection to over 100 different games. Thanks very much, Mr. Bauza - especially from my wallet.
But seriously: Thanks very much, Mr. Bauza. I don't think a nice light-hearted game could get much better than this - or any better looking. If you want to show any non-gamer that boardgames don't suck, start here.

item.name: Tales & Games: Little Red Riding Hood
item.comment: The two modes play (and should be evaluated) very differently. The coop mode is just an okay push-your-luck, I guess a way how to teach your children the basics of risk evaluation. Not much depth, but still a great minigame (this is what Welcome To The Dungeon should have been). The wolf-vs-players mode, though, that's a different story. Pure essence of bluffing. Yep, still a minigame without much depth, but cute looking. Sadly, I lack the comparison, as this is nearly the only fairy tale known in Czech Republic - of all the fairytales that Tales & Games series is based on.

item.name: Taluva
item.comment: Very good principles and the looks of it are a bomb.

item.name: Tarantel Tango
item.comment: This might be the best of the "Kakerlaken" family. Spatial placement adds some fun and while confusing, it's less perplexing than Kakerlaken Salat (which might be because I confuse the words for salad and cauliflower in real life). Requires a house rule to allow to throw some cards during the game (when there's really all five columns of cards, the collecting player might choose one to throw off the game, still collecting the remaining four into his hand), or it's potentionally endless. Lots of laughs, though.

item.name: Tash-Kalar: Arena of Legends
item.comment: As always for Vlaada, there are some interesting and good ideas - and as always for Vlaada, they just don't click together to create a coherent game. This time at least, it doesn't take a whole day to understand the rules, and even though there's pasted fantasy theme, the game is abstract at heart and asymmetric, which is a double plus for me.

item.name: Through the Desert
item.comment: Easy rules, yet some considerable depth. The camels are cute and my collection was heavily missing some game with camels. :) I heartily recommend the "Variations" here on BGG, with drawing a few extra cards in the beginning, with things to score in the end. It doesn't change the outcome much (and the gameplay at all), but it greatly increases the replayability.

item.name: Thunderstone Advance: Worlds Collide
item.comment: A solid effort, some nice options the player has extra to Dominion and very neatly implemented RPG theme in deckbuilding.

item.name: Tigris & Euphrates
item.comment: Good game. Perhaps it's too hard to get back on track once you've fallen behind... yet you have to sit it thru. And the artwork is awful. Decent core, though.

item.name: Tikal
item.comment: Nice euro, looking a little better than your average one with tight thinking in 10AP per turn.

item.name: Time's Up!
item.comment: If I am asked to pick a party game, it's either this or Ochs & Esel. Way better than Activity, I don't know why it's not way more famous, too.

item.name: Tiny Epic Kingdoms
item.comment: Nice game with terrible illustrations. It probably requires a few plays to see what the races all about. Then again, there is a lot of races, which grants a lot of replayability and you don't get to have a civilization 3X game in a small box, that you can take to a pub with you. Too bad that as soon as your engine starts to build, the game is over, but in the end, that's what it's about. :)

item.name: Tobago
item.comment: Not bad. Will not suggest playing it, will not turn it down, either. The game works, it just feel very random in the end. Very cute though, especially the sculptures made of some form of stone.

item.name: Tokaido
item.comment:
Good looking tile collection, somewhat random and hard to predict the results, but it has some potentional for an occasional play.
Get the Crossroads expansion for more decisions.

item.name: Torres
item.comment: Now this is a tight brain-twister!

item.name: Tsuro
item.comment: No depth, obviously. But what it sets out to do, it does very well. The chinese theme, while unnecessary, looks very nice.

item.name: Tsuro of the Seas
item.comment:
The "neutral" sea monsters are an interesting twist, but they (and a bigger grid) make the game somewhat longer - which might be a bad thing, if someone falls out early. It is a good flavor of the game, I just can't decide if I like this more... or the original Tsuro. I can say for sure that original Tsuro is easier in seeing the paths on the tile, the waves make it somehow messy in few cases.
The original looks prettier, but also less thematic. The monsters in this are nice to look at, though.

item.name: Tumblin' Monkeys
item.comment: Kid's game. But a funny one.

item.name: TZAAR
item.comment: GIPF series is a collection of masterpieces.

item.name: Tzolk'in: The Mayan Calendar
item.comment:
The game works. Somehow but doesn't have the calling "play me again!" as many other euros do - at least for me.
UPDATE: The expansion Tribes & Prophecies, especially the "Tribes" part, brought the calling. Somehow Variable Player Powers just click for me.

item.name: Tzolk'in: The Mayan Calendar â€“ Tribes & Prophecies
item.comment: This helped the game a lot. Variable Player Powers were what's been missing for a great replayability.

item.name: Valley of the Kings
item.comment: Of all the deckbuilding games I tried (Dominion, Thunderstone Advance, Nightfall, Arctic Scavengers, Quarriors), this one I liked the most. The pure reason is the fact that the scoring cards no longer smirch my deck, because I have to entomb them (kind of destroy) to score them. The decision "to keep the ability or to score the card" is another delightful aspect. However, best in 2.

item.name: Valley of the Kings: Afterlife
item.comment: Basically the same game as Valley of the Kings, only it has some more interesting effects of the cards. The possibility to mix them up to add more variety or more players is a welcomed bonus.

item.name: Viticulture: Complete Collector's Edition
item.comment: Very good game. A slow start and some card drafts are luckier than others, but also some very good ideas (especially one special big worker, which doesn't block fields or doesn't mind blocked fields... but only ONE, so choose carefully). The mechanics and theme are interlocked quite well and mainly... the THEME IS SO CLOSE TO MY HEART!!! :)

item.name: Welcome to the Dungeon
item.comment: Meh. Pretty pictures don't make a game. There are far better push-your-lucks even in children category. It WOULD be a good game, if it could take 6 or 8 people. In 2-4 player count the game competition is far wider, so nope for this one.

item.name: Yggdrasil
item.comment: Great theme and artwork, solid game. Too bad the six evil guys are tokens, not miniatures. A good brain twister for the group, pretty hard to beat even in the basic setup. Which is a plus for me.

item.name: YINSH
item.comment: GIPF series is a collection of masterpieces.

item.name: Ziegen Kriegen
item.comment: I find this far more appealing than a simple trick-taking card game should ever be, for me. And I thought I like complex games... :) Simple yet smart - or, more precisely, forces YOU to be smart.
